author.description: Provide your name as the package creator. This field can be any string if you wish to include an email address or other contact information also.
author.title: Package Author

bugs.description: A publicly accessible URL where issues, suggestions, and bug reports may be filed.
bugs.title: Bugs URL

changelog.description: A publicly accessible URL where update and release notes about the package may be found.
changelog.title: Changelog URL

compatibleCoreVersion.description: Specify the latest Foundry VTT version with which this system's features are confirmed to function properly.
compatibleCoreVersion.title: Compatible Core Version

dependencies.description: Packages can require other modules, systems, or worlds be installed to allow their use. If a package has been installed with dependencies, but its dependencies are missing it cannot be enabled.

manifest.description: The manifest attribute provides an explicit manifest URL to be used for downloading the dependency. If a manifest is not provided, the dependency package must exist in the Foundry VTT website directory.
manifest.title: Manifest URL

name.description: Dependency entries require the name attribute. If only a name is provided, additional details about the package will be discovered from the Foundry VTT website listing.
name.title: Package Name

type.description: The type attribute instructs Foundry VTT that the dependency may be on a different type of package. By default dependencies are assumed to be module, so if you want to depend on a system or world you should be explicit.
type.title: Package Type

dependencies.title: Dependencies

description.description: This field can contain a more lengthy description of the module. This text can be used to describe the functionality, list contact information, provide recommendations to contributors or testers, or any other information you feel is important to provide. This field can contain HTML to structure and style your text.
description.title: Package Description

download.description: A public URL that provides a zip archive of the package for the manifest version which points to it. The archive at this URL is retrieved during the installation or update process.
download.title: Download URL

esmodules.description: In addition to including traditional JavaScript script files, you may also include JS files which use the newer ES module specification. These files are identified separately in the manifest so they may be correctly loaded as an ES module rather than a script.

items.description: An ES module file path relative to the root directory of the manifest.
items.title: ES Module File

esmodules.title: ES Modules

languages.description: The package may designate an array of languages specifications that it supports by default. Each element in the languages array is an object which defines the language tag, label, and path to its localization file.

lang.description: A language code in lower-case letters, for example 'en' for English. See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-2_codes
lang.title: Language Code

name.description: The formal and readable name for the language.
name.title: Language Name

path.description: A file path relative to the root directory of the manifest where localization strings are provided in JSON format.
path.title: A string value

languages.title: Languages

license.description: A path to a license file relative to the root directory of the manifest or a publicly accessible URL which contains the software license that applies to this package.
license.title: A string value

minimumCoreVersion.description: Specify the latest Foundry VTT version which this package features are confirmed to function properly.
minimumCoreVersion.title: Minimum Core Version

name.description: Choose a unique package identifier. This should be an all lower-case string with no special characters. This name must align with the name of the parent directory within which you create the package.
name.title: Package Name

readme.description: A path to a readme file relative to the root module folder or a publicly accessible URL which contains instructions or information about the package.
readme.title: Read Me

scripts.description: An array of JavaScript file paths included whenever this package is enabled. Each listed script path should be relative to the package root directory. All scripts which exist will be automatically included in the game session and loaded in their listed order.

items.description: JavaScript file path; should be relative to the package root directory.
items.title: Script Entry

scripts.title: Scripts

socket.description: A package may request a specialized socket namespace to be provided allowing data messages to be passed between connected clients. If set to true, a socket event will be handled by the server with the event name `module.{name}` or `system.{name}` depending on your package type. This event name relays arbitrary data packets between the sending client and all other connected clients.
socket.title: Socket

styles.description: You can designate CSS files which are included in the game session whenever this package is enabled. Each listed stylesheet file path should be relative to the system root directory. All stylesheets which exist will be automatically included in the game session and loaded in their listed order.

items.description: CSS file path; should be relative to the system root directory.
items.title: Style Entry

styles.title: Styles

title.description: Provide a human readable title for the package which is displayed as the visible name in the Foundry VTT setup menu and elsewhere.
title.title: Title

url.description: A public URL that links to the repository or documentation pages for the package. This link is displayed to users allowing them to find more information about your package. If your package is hosted in version control like GitHub or GitLab, linking to the repository in this field is a good choice.
url.title: URL

version.description: The package version number can be a number or a string which denotes the version of your package. We recommend using semantic versioning but this is not strictly required. When making changes to your package, incrementing the version number in your manifest file is used to signal to users that an update is available.
version.errorMessage: should be a string or number
version.title: Version
